pros: I am learning and growing professionally. Collaborate work environment.
cons: The expectations are high for employees

review_title: Staff and Administration Care About the Students
pros: I have worked for a variety of institutions over the years. Despite that many proprietary institutions receive a bad reputation, this one has many leaders who care about more than simply putting money in their pockets. Everyone from the upper levels to the entry-level positions are here for the right reasons. They care about the students and helping individuals achieve their career and educational goals. If you are someone who cares about making a difference, this is a place for you. They also offer competitive salaries. Most other colleges will pay less for their respective roles than you will experience here.
cons: - PTO/Holidays - Unlike a traditional school, there is very limited time off that is given. Classes for students move fairly quickly, which means that support staff is needed on a regular basis. That limits the amount of holidays that the staff receives. Although PTO is standard, the first scheduled holiday after New Year's Day is Memorial Day. -Expensive Benefits - Most individuals, especially at the upper levels of administration don't use the benefits that South College offers. They are costly and barely provide much useful coverage.

pros: The faculty and staff are amazing. I work with a team that builds me up daily and cares about my future success. I have grown professionally and personally since working here. South College is a great institution to work for.
cons: No cons. I love working here

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Knoxville, TN
pros: Fantastic training on student learning and faculty grading options. All grades are assigned by rubrics, so the grading is consistent and fair.
cons: There is no faculty culture to speak of. There may be a chili cook-off or a required community service event, but there is no sense of being a faculty member that exists at other places.

pros: Benefits I would say are average.
cons: Insurance could be better than average.

job_title: Student Success Advisor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great location in Cranberry township. Colleagues are nice.
cons: Benefits are not good. For profit- big push to enroll students and do not have their best interest in mind. Micromanagement and review your phone calls. Long and terrible hours.

job_title: Associate Dean of Nursing in Atlanta, GA
pros: Salary was competitive and the campus and equipment is very nice
cons: Leadership gaslighted staff and employees who called it out we’re not supported.

pros: Excellent pay but not worth the stress.
cons: Horrible management, nepotism is apparent

pros: South College is big enough to make a difference in our community but small enough to offer employees a family atmosphere and culture where hard work is recognized and valued.
cons: None! The future is very bright for South College.

review_title: Poor work life balance, culture of trial by fire and micro management
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Atlanta, GA
pros: Not sure if there are any.
cons: Micromanagement in every department, accusatory culture, more worried about numbers than staff, faculty or especially the students. Was there for over 2 years and went through 3 program directors. Class size is 80 students so if they don't keep up its on them since faculty are maxed out in class, lab and have to drive 2 hours to to teach clinicals. Work load credit is so low you can't manage all the class responsibility and the students get a mediocre education and teach themselves.

review_title: Great Pay. Not So Great Benefits
pros: The pay is great The work is easy Coworkers are really nice, helpful, and cool
cons: The benefits cover almost nothing They are constantly changing the enrollment process There is little room for promotions You are hardly recognized for anything good you do unless you're a favorite You have no time for a personal life

pros: Helping students change their life and reach their end gaol.
cons: Some days can be really busy

review_title: I would never work for this company again
pros: The school is in a safe area and the salaries are competitive.
cons: The campus is poorly managed, policies are applied inconsistently, and the campus culture leans towards cattiness and discriminatory practices.

review_title: Great place to work hard and have a good time doing it.

cons: -Not many holidays -Minimal PTO starting out -PTO and sick days are not separate for full-time staff

pros: You have to work unreasonable hours
cons: Good staff and faculty to work with

cons: Very hard to have a work life balance.

pros: You get your own office
cons: No PTO of any kind until you've been working there for 12 months You have to work some weekends You are carefully monitored throughout the day Poor management style Very high turnover

pros: I like the work that I do and the people I work with. With as much growth as we've had recently, it's nice to have a reliable team to ensure all the work gets done. My superiors are kind and flexible, and this is easily my favorite job thus far in my career.
cons: No cons at this time!

cons: Would like to be able to provide more resources to students who need financial and emotional support.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Knoxville, TN
pros: Friendly colleagues at the Lonas campus
cons: Administration only cares about enrolling and retaining students for $$$. Faculty are micromanaged and distrusted. Administrators created a workplace environment that is so toxic that I have PTSD from working there.

job_title: Student Learning Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Worked with some great staff and faculty
The facilities were usually clean
The landscaping is immaculate
Great pay
Good work experience
cons:
Terrible communication 
Neither diverse nor inclusive
Doesn't have students best interests at heart
Doesn't provide the support students need 
Questionable practices regarding students who require accommodations
High turnover
Sterile and impersonal decor
It was made clear to me before I accepted my position that the college president did not want anyone walking on the grass (seriously)
Did not feel valued

pros: The only pro of working here is that you’ll have something new to discuss with your therapist
cons:
I have one piece of advice: RUN. 

If you have a strong sense of integrity and sincerity, you might not belong in this environment. During my experience here, I observed that most employees of the school viewed students as numbers rather than human beings. “An enrollment is an enrollment” is a phrase members of management often used in my presence to justify enrolling vulnerable students, particularly when pursuing an education (at a private $$$ institution) is not in the student’s best interest due to financial hardship, family situations, or other extenuating circumstances. There is a certain stigma associated with for-profit institutions, and South College certainly fit the bill in my opinion. Ultimately, it got to the point where I could no longer sleep at night working for this school. Overall a terrible experience for me. I truly don’t see this company lasting another 5 years because the truth will out eventually.

pros: One of the most professional and positive environments I have been associated with in some time. Everyone works together and collaborates really well and there is no drama or problems at all. Faculty and staff are great and just want the best for the students. Also the computers and equipment we have is definitely some of the nicest and everything is always so clean and cared for.
cons: I wish there was more parking sometimes and maybe less meetings. But I don't have anything negative to say.

pros: Absolutely none that I can think of.
cons: Poor work life balance, micromanaging, undermining of staff, student grade inflation, favoritism, horrible benefits, zero time off/PTO.

review_title: I did not have a good experience here.
job_title: Student Success Advisor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I believe I was paid relatively fairly for my role and my experience/education.
cons: We had to work 9-6 each day (which I recognize is a relatively small complaint). The work was draining - I was on the phone almost all day with students - and I felt that the company's business model was predatory and took advantage of students who lacked an understanding of the difference between a for-profit and a non-profit institution of higher education. I felt morally compromised in my role and as if I could do very little, if anything, to actually help my students. I started looking for a new position after only a month or so in this role. It was not a good fit for me at all.

pros: Strong compensation, great colleagues, student focused strategies
cons: Need to perform your job!

pros: They expose you to all red flags early on, as soon as you see their training model even, so you are not stuck in your position miserable for very long. 2 months to a year tops is all it takes for any well aware individual to realize all the dysfunctional systems and unfair policies South College (Nashville specifically) retains. The pro is you will get to see the fast turnover as a chance to meet lots of new friends cycling in and out to job hunt for other opportunities together on your micro-managed lunch breaks.
cons:
Where do we begin?

1. Don't have any kind of personal/family emergency that requires you to leave the office for any reason. And do not even attempt to file for FMLA in an extreme emergency. You will just need to quit entirely at that point. You will be berated and questioned heavily, so far as to break HIPPA laws to determine if your need to leave is "justified". HR and all of management are ruthlessly unforgiving, and will ask probing questions and worst of all, gossip amongst themselves about your traumas and personal life.

1a. In regards to gossiping: all of management are friends with each other outside of work, so will frequently spend the weekends socializing and gossiping about employees under them. During the week, they will stay behind closed doors together regularly heard laughing and ranting about work and the employees far from discreetly.

****2. Upper management's "commitment to diversity" means hiring 1-2 people of color for the whole college, and showing fake favoritism to one over the other. Management shared facetious smiles and cheesy email shoutouts, but never offered any real promotions, professional recognition, or additional benefits to showcase their significant outperformance of everyone else on the team. The employees of color were continuously commented on for appearances and "attitudes". This is a topic that can be elaborated on in a lengthy essay format, so I would advise and prospective or current employee to research all the former and current lawsuits against South College in reference to their diversity and inclusion insufficiencies.

3. The office environment was always filled with negative competitiveness created by the harsh sales metrics and meaningless praise each week, drama between employees and management, hot tempers, and uneasy feelings. You always felt like you were being watched. Calls are recorded, for legal reasons, yet you know you were constantly being monitored/listened to and judged for "training purposes". You couldn't make small talk with your coworkers for longer than 30 seconds without eyes peeping around the corner signaling to break it up. 

4. The covid policies and procedures almost left everyone in the office without a job or sick. Management arrived to work, knowing they were sick with covid, risking everyone else in the office, and we were instructed to keep it within admissions. No other departments or students were notified of the potential exposure, although admissions had had contact with students and other departments every day, which is a moral and health and safety disaster. Approving time off for covid was nearly impossible as well. Additionally, when the vaccine was being offered at the school, you were made to feel extremely guilty if you chose to opt out and seek your own vaccine site or otherwise. All of HRs policies around covid were so unsafe, and work from home was never on the table for positions and job duties that the department could have easily made exceptions for.

5. All attempts to foster a positive work environment felt forced and proved to be moot. Friday mornings were spent in trainings and department get togethers sometimes sponsored with bagels or coffee. If there were treats at one of these meetings, this usually meant there was an underlying purpose to stir up issues, talk about drama in the department, and show unfair favoritism under the guise of "professionalism training". There was no way to feel personal or welcome on this team without faking your personality or professionalism in such a tense environment. 

6. All of the tech and systems the college uses are out of date and convoluted. There are too many separate systems that are used for too many different functions that are hard to learn. They have a poor sales system and tracking, which make it harder for reps to be on top of their outlandish goals in the first place. The whole process needs to be streamlined to make it easier both on employee and student. 

7. Internet and power outages in the building. Also, building maintenance, in general, seemed to always be unreliable between frequent outages, broken elevators, construction, TERRIBLE PARKING, and regularly broken heat/ac in the coldest and warmest months.

8. There was always the moral dilemma of selling a school and program to students who were vulnerable and unaware of the business model a for-profit school like South College provides. We were trained to literally manipulate students, who were clearly in no financial position to spend $50k on a 2 year program to invest and come up with false solutions. The retention rate is so low at South College for exactly this reason; admissions lies to them to get them into classes, and they drop when they can't meet the unrealistic expectations, the curriculum/instruction is low quality, and of course the blasphemous financial burden. The CEO and upper management takes no time in choosing programs and instructors (and tuition pricing) for the students themselves, but solely for the highest paying programs. They do this by investing a lot of money into top quality facilities, for attraction and good marketing. But what good is a fully operational high-tech dental clinic, if the aspiring dental students are not all graduating and alternatively choosing irreparable debt that's just lining the CEO's pockets. The overall attitude toward the business model feels completely and utterly about the owners and founders benefit, and not an ounce about the well-being and success of students choosing career-focused programs.

9. The whole benefit plan is garbage. Insurance plans are ridiculously expensive, time-off policies will chain you to your desk begging for a break and defending your reasoning for vacation etc.

cons:

pros: I Wish there were any
cons: Bad environment, bad management, no perks of the job.

pros: The salary with SC is competitive.
cons: You are not respected and valued for your talents and skillsets. It's about popularity and favorites.

job_title: Student Success Advisor in Cranberry, PA
pros: None. I have nothing good to say.
cons:
1) rude and smart communication, unprovoked 
2) the benefits are terrible - they’re expensive for one, there’s no sick leave, you get 15 days a year of PTO and if you run out of PTO you have to wait until the following year. There’s no parental leave, paid or otherwise. If you ever need to work from home for any reason the request will be denied,  even though you work for south college *online* and don’t need to be in the office to do your job.
3) if you stand up for yourself, you will be harassed and retaliated against 
4) the handling of Covid was abominable. Made us return to the office as cases of flu and Covid continued to spike, and when people got sick in the office, still did not send everyone home. They would send a department home for a week, as if we all didn’t work in the same building and use the same bathrooms and break rooms. The mask mandate was dropped a year ago and the Covid policy changed to, if you catch Covid without vaccination you have to use PTO or take unpaid leave if you’re out of PTO, and even if you’re vaccinated, your request has to be approved through upper management. Also, you can be written up for the unpaid leave you were forced to take.
5) turnover is high
6) they do not care about students or workers. They care about their bottom line.
7) we are expected to harass students by calling them multiple times on the phone even though it’s the 21st century and most students prefer to talk via text or email.
8) The annual “raises” are abysmal, and we are not paid enough for the work load we’re expected to handle
9) there is no diversity in upper management and barely any amongst co-workers 
10) the training is nonexistent. You will essentially be teaching yourself for the most part and then they throw you to the wolves
11) you are held responsible for students that stay or leave 
12) the business model and practices are outdated and out of touch with students and workers which impacts work culture. 
13) with a 9-6 schedule, work on Saturdays, and no option to work from home, there is no work life balance. The campus was moved during the first year of the pandemic to a location that requires you to pay a toll for everyone who doesn’t live in Cranberry, PA, or travel 45-60 minutes to get there.  The former campus president lives there, but he no longer works for the college but everyone else must still pay 200 a month in tolls or suffer through that long commute. I have to get up 2.5 hours before my shift just to make it on time.
14) There are little to no opportunities for growth here, especially if you’re not a part of the good ole boys crew.

pros: Sundays you don’t have to work
cons: Monday -Saturday you have to work

job_title: Current Employee In Atlanta, GA (US) in Atlanta, GA

review_title: College should never be run under a business model
pros: Very much like the faculty I work with and enjoy the students
cons:
Management does not treat staff well
Decisions are made by the top level of administration about areas in which they have not expertise
Administrators seem to be chosen on a "buddy system"
Staff are fired at will and openly in front of other employees
Administration speaks of retention but the policies go against retention
Benefits run along the lines of a corporation-- very little PTO (15 days total for vacation and sick and cannot be carried over). Also if you retire or resign, any unused PTO is not payed out. 
Staff are monitored on their phone by administration and their computer activities monitored
Policies are not followed equally for staff, faculty, or students
The bottom line is the number of incoming students and convincing them stay no matter what situation might be best for the student

pros: None to mention at this time
cons: Everything is wrong with this place don't even waste your time.

review_title: Don't work here. Narrow minded people.
pros: Higher than average wages.
cons: Narrow minded and untrained management. I witnessed management being disrespectful to students many times and being extremely rude to them. Some management is terrible, mistrusting, homophobic and bigoted. The owners who live in TN made the wood office doors nearly all glass doors because they dont trust staff in their own offices and that way staff can't have privacy even behind closed doors. Don't take it personally. The whole place is that way. Mismanagement is putting it kindly. Students were abused verbally and lied to about the competition in surrounding area (with other schools) so that students wouldn't enroll there. Students told me they were dismissed when they asked questions, although they were told different reasons. It was a horrible place to work, a nightmare from day one when my boss began critiquing what other staff members were wearing, putting them down, talking badly about staff members. Juvenile inappropriate behavior from managment.

pros: To gain experience toward getting a better job. You will learn how to do things with a minimal amount of support and resources, which can be challenging yet rewarding at the same time. It can be wonderful to work with faculty and students.
cons: It is a stuffy, cold environment. Some members of administration have very short fuses and do not treat their employees well. It is a for-profit college. Individual department budgets are not set in stone. Individual departments are often not allowed to use all of what the administration approved for them. Receiving collections calls for overdue invoices is uncomfortable. Too much focus is put on appearances. Compensation is low.

pros: Good compensation and benefits. Fellow faculty and students are great to work with. It is very rewarding to watch students grow professionally and succeed after graduation. The college is supportive of faculties continuing education and participation in conferences by providing time off and financial assistance. The faculty at South College truly care about the students success.
cons: Upper management does not always understand or know what is going on at the front line. South College is a for profit school so financial gain is an overriding theme. However, I have seen this same emphasis on money at nonprofit schools as well.

job_title: Student Success Adviser in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I was paid well and enjoyed the opportunity to work with students and support them during their college journey. It was also an easy hiring process.
cons: I only took this job because I was desperate, and it pretty much turned out to be exactly what I expected. This is a for-profit college, so the school is much more focused on making money than only truly providing students with a good education. During COVID-19, we were asked to come back to the office even though virtually ALL of my work could be done remotely. Once in the office, few people actually followed social distance guidelines and mask-wearing guidelines. I often saw senior management walking around close to other people without wearing masks. I would recommend only working here if you have NO other option.

pros: Fantastic technology, nice office spaces, top of the line classrooms, knowledgeable staff, kind professors, attractive surroundings
cons:
Cold, sterile environment. Administration does not help create engagement among staff. Distrust and micro-management from leadership levels. Pay was lower than industry standards. Leave time benefits were scarce and not encouraged.

I once heard the president referred to as Mr. Oz...the man hiding behind the curtain. I never saw him the entire time I worked there.

review_title: Run, Don't Walk, tHe Other Way!!!
pros: Front-Line co-workers wonderful to work with! They care about their job & their quality of work.
cons: Bullying management style & it starts from the top.  Everyone is assumed to not be doing anything unless they prove they are doing something (& it only convinces them briefly). Not all employees are given the same rules or treatment.  Misuse of security cameras.  Support Staff are a necessary evil that they have to waste money on, in the eyes of upper management.  Admissions Department operates on a "burn 'em & turn 'em" philosophy.  They only care about money & not about people (employees as well as students).
